title: Command Line Basics
description: Master the basics of the Linux command line.

sections.text: Dive into the world of the Linux command line!
The command line, also known as the terminal or shell, is a powerful tool for interacting with your Linux system.
Opening the Terminal
To open the terminal, you can typically find it in the applications menu or by pressing `Ctrl+Alt+T`.
Basic Commands
Here are some basic commands to get you started:

sections.code:
ls # List files and directories
cd # Change directory
pwd # Print working directory
mkdir # Create a new directory
cp # Copy files and directories
mv # Move or rename files and directories
rm # Remove files and directories
cat # Display file contents
nano # Open the nano text editor

sections.text: Command Options and Arguments
Most commands accept options and arguments to modify their behavior. For example:

sections.code:
ls -l # List files in a long format
cp -r mydir newdir # Copy directory recursively

sections.text: Navigating the File System
Use the `cd` command to change directories and navigate through the file system. For example:

sections.code:
cd /home/user/documents # Change to the 'documents' directory
cd .. # Go up one directory level

sections.text: Creating and Removing Files and Directories
Use the `touch`, `mkdir`, and `rm` commands to create and remove files and directories:

sections.code:
touch file.txt # Create a new empty file
mkdir mydir # Create a new directory
rm file.txt # Remove a file
rm -r mydir # Remove a directory recursively

sections.text: Practice Exercise: Create a new directory called 'practice' in your home directory, navigate into it, create a new file called 'hello.txt', and then remove the file and directory.
Viewing File Contents
Use the `cat`, `head`, and `tail` commands to view the contents of files:

sections.code:
cat file.txt # Display the entire file
head file.txt # Display the first 10 lines of the file
tail file.txt # Display the last 10 lines of the file

sections.text: Practice Exercise: Create a new file called 'sample.txt' with some sample text, and use the `cat`, `head`, and `tail` commands to view its contents.
File Permissions
Use the `chmod` command to change file permissions:

sections.code:
chmod 644 file.txt # Set read/write permissions for the owner and read permissions for others
chmod +x script.sh # Add execute permission to a script

sections.text: Practice Exercise: Create a new file and use the `chmod` command to change its permissions. Observe how the permissions affect your ability to read, write, and execute the file.
Getting Help
To get help on a command, you can use the `man` command followed by the command name. For example:

sections.code: man ls # Display the manual page for the ls command

sections.text: Practice using these commands and exploring their options. The more you work with the command line, the more comfortable and efficient you'll become!
